title: Thursday, 1st December, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

Good morning

PM11:01am

Very important anniversary today, here at FTAV HQ

PM11:01am

Very important indeed

11:02 am
PM11:02am

Kadhim Shubber has completed has first year as an Alphavillain

PM11:02am

So he get's his pick up here

PM11:02am

11:02 am
PM11:02am

Thumbs up

PM11:03am

We're also celebrating the one year anniversary of Nikkei taking over the FT

PM11:03am

So that's triggered all sorts of celebratory company-wide emails from the top brass

11:03 am
PM11:03am

None of which I'm going to share here

PM11:03am

As Bryce has noted, off line, tho...

BE11:04am

.........

11:03 am
PM11:04am

A third of us would be in PR by now if Axel Springer had bought us

BE11:04am

Probably not the right third either.

PM11:04am

Half of us would be in PR if Pearson had not sold us

11:04 am
PM11:05am

Nikkei have been good to the FT. They haven't rolled us in money, but they've kept the lights on

BE11:05am

Yup. As it is, we're very happy to still be doing what we've always done, among approximately the same number of people.

PM11:05am

(Call me Papi
-- what's the prob?)

11:05 am
PM11:06am

Before we get into markets can I just ask people to give us their views on this....

BE11:06am

................................................. go on.

PM11:06am

https://ftalphavil...pen-the-long-room/

11:06 am
PM11:06am

Do leave a comment there not here

PM11:06am

Wink smile

undefined
11:06 am
PM11:06am

So Bryce

PM11:07am

Oilers up

PM11:07am

Glencore resuming divis

11:07 am
PM11:07am

RIo in hot water with the SEC

PM11:07am

What to go with?

BE11:07am

We can start with the miners, since it's the obvious place.

11:07 am
BE11:08am

They're down, mostly. Why?

BE11:08am

Well, because they're up 100% as a sector YTD.

BE11:08am

What more do you want? Jeez.

11:08 am
BE11:08am

In terms of Glencore .....

PM11:08am

Incredible

Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 280.35, up 1.05 (+0.38%), High: 289.40, Low: 280.30, Volume: 20.13m
11:09 am
BE11:09am

Yes, you're getting a divi! A year after an emergency rescue rights issue! And two years after a massive share buyback!

BE11:10am

It's almost like Ivan doesn't know that he's doing. But of course he does! I'm going to stop with the exclamation marks now!

PM11:10am

Details here http://www.investe...1612010700056179Q/

11:10 am
PM11:10am

Slides go up at noon

PM11:11am

And the divi policy stuff:

PM11:11am

New distribution policy to take effect from 2018 comprising:

o a fixed $1 billion base distribution, reflecting the resilience, predictability and stability of Marketing cash flows; plus

o a variable distribution representing a minimum payout of 25% of Industrial free cash flow

11:11 am
BE11:11am

As well as the divi next year you're getting a commitment to lower through-the-cycle leverage. So hopefully no more emergency rights issues.

BE11:11am

(Or massive share buybacks.)

BE11:11am

Here's RBC to summarise it all.

11:11 am
BE11:12am

Our view: The announcement of the completion of the deleveraging program as well as the restoration of the dividend caps a 2016 that few would have thought
possible at the start of the year. The dividend for 2017 of cents per share, or a 2% dividend yield is a good start - but from 2018 the minimum US$1bn payout
7
which is based on the stable marketing cash flows, topped up by 25% of the industrial cashflow, should allow for a further rerating in the multiple as income
investors return to the story. With free cashflow at indicative 2017 prices of $6.5bn, this should provide a strong uplift for 2018 dividends. Other positives that
should help maintain the momentum include the arketing guidance for 2016 moved to the top end of the range and net debt coming in below our $17.7bn year
m
end target. Although on a valuation basis Glencore is trading closer to fair value on our numbers we see this mornings news allowing for the shares to push on.

BE11:12am

And UBS.

BE11:12am

1) Dividend yield likely ~5% in 2018; 2) FCF yield ~14% based on forward prices 1) Dividend: GLEN has committed to pay $1bn in 2017 in equal tranches in H1 & H2 (yield ~2%); this is slightly below UBSe as GLEN looks to get its BBB- credit rating lifted. The policy from 2018 is to pay a fixed $1bn distribution (reflecting robust Marketing cash flow) and a minimum of 25% of Industrial FCF; based on GLEN's 2017 FCF indication of $6.5bn, this implies a minimum distribution of ~$2.2bn in 2018 (yield ~5%). 2) Strong FCF: GLEN estimates 2017 FCF at ~$6.5bn & EBITDA at ~$14bn based on 2017 forward prices (Cu ~$2.70/lb, Zn ~$1.30/lb) & a conservative coal price (~$73/t); this is below UBSe spot EBITDA of $15.8bn due to coal (spot $87/t).

11:13 am
BE11:13am

3) Marketing improving; 4) Deleveraging on track; 4) Disposals largely done 3) Marketing: this is expected to be in the "upper end" of the $2.5-2.7bn guided range (in line with UBSe of $2.7bn); this implies H2 Marketing EBIT of $1.5bn (H1 $1.2bn). 4) Deleveraging: GLEN expects net debt to be in its $16.5-17.5bn target range by end-16, down from $26bn in Dec-15; this implies net debt to EBITDA falls to ~1.2x in 2017 (based on GLEN's indicated EBITDA at forward prices), well below the target maximum level of 2x through the cycle. 4) Disposals: GLEN has raised $6.3bn from disposals vs initial target of $1-2bn; GLEN has previously stated it is looking to sell Vasilkovskoye gold mine, but in our opinion they are only likely to sell this if the value is attractive.

BE11:13am

They're buyers.

BE11:13am

In our opinion, GLEN has a compelling valuation and an attractive mix (with Cu, Zn, Ni well positioned and coal floor price supported by China policy); we expect the share to re-rate as returns step up. Tgt is based on 0.8x NPV for Industrial/ 12x PE for Marketing.

11:13 am
BE11:14am

...... On earnings estimates that are approximately twice the consensus.

PM11:14am

Forecasts are that wide?

BE11:15am

Yup. Push out to 2018 and it's wild stabbing in the dark based on what your thermal coal curve looks like. Which rather underlines how tricky it is to figure out where Glencore should be trading.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Hang on, not thermal. The other one. You know what I mean.

PM11:15am

Yeah, get the picture

undefined
11:16 am
BE11:16am

In terms of the wider mining picture ..... we have Haitong saying take profits.

BE11:16am

We downgrade BLT, GLEN, ANTO and VALE from Neutral to Sell and RIO from Buy to Neutral. We see many of the catalysts driving miners at present as eventually fading: bulk commodity prices are likely to ease in 2017, and emerging risks to global growth are likely to outweigh long-dated and uncertain benefits from post-US election stimulus. We think recent strength is an opportunity to take profits.

BHP Billiton PLC (BLT:LSE): Last: 1,309, down 5 (-0.38%), High: 1,361, Low: 1,308, Volume: 3.33m
11:16 am
Antofagasta PLC (ANTO:LSE): Last: 671.00, down 18 (-2.61%), High: 699.00, Low: 670.00, Volume: 1.68m
BE11:17am

The argument is "take profits".

BE11:17am

Selling Outperformance: Catalysts have built in miners this year, helped in turn by balance sheet relief, sterling weakness, rallying bulk commodity prices and now hopes for resurgent demand, even shrugging off a resurgent dollar. But miners are now trading above our DCF valuations across the board. If we mark-to-market spot commodities they do look relatively cheap (2017e PE 5-8x for RIO/AAL/GLEN), with ND:EBITDA falling below 1x for all miners, and this is likely driving some renewed enthusiasm for the sector. It is, however, misplaced. We are now well above incentive prices in bulk commodities, and there is spare and new capacity in both iron ore and coal that can be brought to the market in 2017. Also, miners always look misleadingly cheap (and expensive) at MTM valuations during commodity spikes/troughs; this helps momentum, but is usually a counter-indicator of value.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

...... So take profits.

BE11:17am

Commodity price hopes: We raise our 2017 forecast for coking coal 80% to USD180/t and our thermal price 30% to USD70/t. These are 30%/41% below spot prices for thermal/coking coal, but above the prices we think will bring on spare capacity over the course of 2017. We have added USD5/t to our 2017 iron ore forecast (to bring it to USD50/t), and see additional supply coming to the market irrespective of prices over the next six months.

We are leaving our other forecasts largely unchanged and not factoring a broader stimulus-driven revival that the market seems to think possible post the US presidential election. We see this as long dated, with delivery risk and not overly material to the global market given the maturity of the US as a metal market. It is no coincidence that rising globalisation over the past 15 years has coincided in the most significant commodity cycle in decades – as rising trade and the relocation of manufacturing has a significant compounding effect on materials (lowering manufacturing cost, boosting materials demand due to new capital investment and for workforce urbanisation). Globalisation and the commodity super cycle went hand in hand and a potential rising tide of protectionism is now a medium-term structural threat.

BE11:17am

Because take profits, that's why.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Strategy reversals? The rapid rebound in commodity prices makes several decisions now look knee-jerk. The uneven price spike is a very strong argument for diversification and against the ability for company boards to pick winners. The prime example is Anglo’s asset sale strategy which now looks wrong, but it’s been spared embarrassment by not executing on it. The abandonment of progressive dividends now looks like panicking at the bottom of the cycle, although the shift to pay-out ratios is a positive by-product of this longer term in our view. Although we don’t see any sudden reversal of the huge decline in capex spending, it now seems we are at the bottom of the capex cycle and there is now room for longer-term project development and exploration, relieving the unrelenting downward pressure on suppliers.

BE11:18am

Andrew Keen's the analyst there.

PM11:18am

Interesting

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Though if you don't fancy taking profits, UBS can help you with that rationalisation too.

BE11:19am

Don't buy stinkers, they say. That's their advice.

BE11:19am

In our opinion, the commodity backdrop is favourable going into 2017 with Chinese (and US) demand likely to be robust due to the government transitions/ fiscal stimulus. We also believe the backdrop for the mining sector is positive as even without material commodity price upside, the majority of the industrial miners generate strong free cash flow (greater than 10% FCF yield) and have the potential to lift shareholder returns in 2017/18. We do however believe the risk/ reward differs materially between the commodities, with iron ore & coal prices set to fall from elevated levels as supply steps up, while copper, zinc & nickel increase as deficits emerge/ increase. As a result, we expect 2017 to be a commodity & stock-picking year.

11:20 am
PM11:20am

Easier said than done

BE11:20am

We see this a lot. Analysts predicting that the year ahead will be a "stock-picking year"

BE11:21am

They only seem to predict it on the back of a giant sector-wide one-tide-all-boats rerating. But I don't remember many start-of-year previews predicting those.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Analysts, I guess, like stock picking. Given it's their job.

BE11:21am

Back to UBS.

BE11:21am

We prefer base metal exposure over bulks, and expect stocks that are first to convert strong FCF into a meaningful lift in shareholder returns to outperform. Our top pick is Glencore driven by its strong 2017 FCF yield at spot of 19% & our belief that it re-instate a material dividend in 2017, and Norilsk Nickel due to its exposure to near-term nickel price upside & sector leading 2017 dividend yield of 9%. We prefer Rio over BHP as Rio will be in a position to step up returns in 2017 and has restructuring potential.

11:21 am
BE11:22am

In the mid-caps, our top pick is KAZ Minerals as a leveraged play on copper (with growth). Antofagasta and Boliden are also well positioned from a commodity mix perspective but in our opinion their valuations are not compelling. South32 generates strong FCF at spot of 28%, has a net cash position, and is likely to step up returns in 2017; however, in our opinion, the share is likely to consolidate while coal, alumina and manganese ore prices fall over the next 3-6 months (similar to Anglo American).

BE11:22am

The UBS commodity team lifts its 2017 copper forecast by 30% to $3.00/lb and zinc 27% to $1.40/lb; they also lift iron ore & coal prices expecting a slower retracement. This results in 2017 EBITDA upgrades for the majors of ~35% with EPS ~85%; 2018 is also lifted, while 2019 is broadly unchanged. Our 12m forward NPVs increase by ~10% due to strong near-term FCF as a result of commodity price upgrades and roll-forward.

BE11:22am

(@roddy1234: that's the fella. Ta.)

11:22 am
undefined

And how about Rio?

PM11:23am

How's that responding to this SEC stuff?

Yep, and it seems food/beverages is today's problem area.

Unilever PLC (ULVR:LSE): Last: 3,054, down 142.5 (-4.46%), High: 3,158, Low: 3,052, Volume: 1.74m
PM11:27am

Ouch

11:27 am
Coca Cola HBC AG (CCH:LSE): Last: 1,643, down 57 (-3.35%), High: 1,700, Low: 1,640, Volume: 110.71k
Compass Group PLC (CPG:LSE): Last: 1,330, down 41 (-2.99%), High: 1,367, Low: 1,329, Volume: 1.06m
BE11:28am

We've noted previously that these are among the worst performers post Trump.

11:01 am
PM11:01am

Welcome to Markets Live

BE11:29am

There is that, certainly. Plus the emerging markets exposure.

BE11:30am

More pertinent to today, though, is some grumbling about Unilever's investor day.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Citi -- still a buyer -- cuts forecasts but glosses it in a lot of Unilever's presentation bumf.

BE11:31am

[The meeting] confirmed our view that Unilever’s mix of EM scale, where Route To Market remains a barrier to entry, and portfolio management allows for a non-disruptive implementation of cost savings. The new guidance for 40-80bps margin expansion over 2017-19 is indeed not just the result of a Zero-Based-Budgeting (ZBB) programme, but also the product of a unique portfolio where cost cutting does not necessarily penalise top-line growth.

BE11:31am

(They're buyers.)

11:31 am
BE11:32am

Barriers to entry in rural EM, which Unilever dominates, coupled with the capacity to reinvest savings into new channels and multiple brands, are translating into 30bps aggregate market share gains, while other multinationals have lost 50bps of share, in particular to more agile local players. This trend highlights in our view how portfolio strength prevails over any other metrics in such an ecosystem, and Unilever has the capacity to optimise its asset mix even further, in our view.

BE11:32am

We estimate that Unilever new targets point toward c8% organic EBIT growth, o/w half comes from margin improvement, i.e. self-help. Coupled with deleveraging (especially given Unilever spectacular cash conversion), our analysis points to a normalised c9% EPS growth algorithm over the long term, which apart from Danone is c200bps above peers

BE11:32am

We expect slower EM pricing and the impact of demonetisation in India to be a drag on organic growth until Q2 17. However, we believe that the emergence of this new earnings growth algorithm is a confirmation of Unilever superior business model, where scale and corporate agility can actually co-exist, supporting a self-help and non-disruptive margin story, coupled with portfolio optionality.

11:32 am
BE11:33am

"Everything's great, except earnings, which aren't as great as they were."

BE11:34am

Meanwhile, "The death of Keynes", says Jefferies.

BE11:34am

ULVR's symbolic return to quantified guidance and a shift in its mix from growth to margin and cash signals that the spirit of Keynesian demand management in staples is being supplanted in favour of Friedmanite supply-side rectitude. Initial market reaction has been positive and we anticipate modest upgrades. But we expect the wider ramifications to do little to lift the crisis of confidence that has descended on the sector.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

(This is Martin Deboo, of course.)

BE11:35am

The shift in delivery is in the roundings. It's the symbolism that is resonating for us this morning. ULVR have felt compelled to offer guidance for the first time in nine years, having famously suspended it in 2009. The balanced ticket of growth, margin & cash contrasts with the 'win share, grow volume and profit and cash will follow' mantra of the early Polman years (the words are ours.) The inference is that ULVR, like NESN, have felt obliged to capitulate to the new verities of perma-deflation in DM's, chronic volatility in EM's and the associated de-stabilising influences of channel shift and more vigorous local competition. It all adds up to a less growth-y, more bond-y model. So, the initial share price bump aside, we suspect this will do little to dispel the current crisis in investor confidence in staples.

BE11:36am

......... You buy a company that makes margarine and you end up worrying about the natural lifespan of Keynsian economics.

11:36 am
PM11:36am

hehehe

BE11:36am

Investing sucks. I don't know why you people bother.

undefined
11:36 am
PM11:37am

Lloyds a tad weaker I see

Lloyds Banking Group plc (LLOY:LSE): Last: 57.11, down 0.76 (-1.31%), High: 58.55, Low: 56.99, Volume: 57.79m
PM11:37am

There's been this Basel committee thing going on in Chile (of all places)

11:37 am
PM11:37am

No agreement on the new rules, but apparently they are getting there

PM11:38am

Devils in the detail on this -- and the detail is way too complicated for me

PM11:38am

But there's a sense that Lloyds is particularly vulnerable on this

11:38 am
PM11:38am

Even tho it did well in the stress tests

PM11:38am

Let me get Jon PIerce of Exane to explain

PM11:38am

Some further thoughts on the Basel Committee speech post the meeting this week in which it sounds like substantial progress was made towards finalising the Basel III standards - colloquially referred to as Basel IV by the market.

We focus in particular on LBG (Underperform) because it is a potential outlier and hence exposed to an overall net negative impact on certain scenarios. Indeed, our highest conviction relative call of Barclays (Outperform) versus LBG is we believe supported by what we read.

11:38 am
PM11:39am

1. The new rules - no details of calibration. Ingves said that he was limited in what he could say ahead of endorsement by the Governors and Heads of Supervision in January. But he was clear that there will be a new set of standardised credit risk weights, that input floors will be applied to internal models, operational risk will move to a standardised approach for all and perhaps most importantly an output floor will apply to modelled risk weights relative to the equivalent standardised approach.

PM11:39am

Exane view: without details on the final rules, a quantitative assessment of the impact is impossible. Standardised risk weight changes are said to be capital neutral but the main focus for the UK banks is how buy to let is treated - 75% risk weight or 35% - and whether models can still be used for this asset class (we suspect so but still not clear). Input floors are potentially important for mortgages in particular where an LGD of 10% was originally proposed at the account level (i.e. not the overall portfolio level). For the UK banks though, the most important detail surrounds operational risk and output floors. We strongly suspect the first component of the op risk calculation where a baseline requirement dependent on the size of the revenue base is generated will remain in its currently proposed form. This will drive up op risk cap requirements to over 20% of revenue for the large UK banks. Barclays is already there but the others are not. Notably LBG is nearer 13% and our estimates suggest this alone could add 7% to its group RWA. The second component, the loss multiplier, is however likely to change with significant pushback in consultation responses pointing to the lack of logic in hitting banks with additional capital requirements for litigation and conduct losses that relate to businesses now exited. But even if we exclude PPI charges from the LBG calculations, this would further increase the impact on the bank of op risk adjustments to over 10% because of other conduct charges. Other UK banks with sizeable historic losses are also likely to suffer in a relative context from this - even if as suggested, the overall impact on the global banking sector is neutral. Finally, on output floors, all depends on the level of such a floor. Original proposals pointed to a potential 60-90% floor and we suspect it will be set at the low end or perhaps even lower in the final rules. The risk here is to banks whose credit IRB portfolios have particularly low risk weights versus the standard rules - in the UK, LBG is the outlier and we estimate its IRB portfolio has an average risk weight of 49% of the equivalent standardised approach. We estimate that a move to 60% would add GBP30bn or 12% to group RWA.

PM11:39am

Told you it was complex

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Uh, yes. I'll read that later.

PM11:39am

There's lots more on this

PM11:39am

Contact Exane for the rest

11:39 am
PM11:40am

Oh, just one extra bit

PM11:40am

4. Will the UK and Europe follow the rules? The speech contains a very large section on the need for compromise. "It is important to note that no single country or region gets everything it wants from the negotiations. If left to their own devices, everyone would write the final rules differently. But as we know, the financial system is global in nature and highly interlinked across jurisdictions and regions. So there is a collective understanding that the benefits of compromise (and giving up a little) which results in a global standard far outweigh the costs of divergence." It then says that, "There is no escaping the broader political and economic issues that shape international policymaking. However, standard setting for global banks should not be viewed as a trade negotiation. The Committee's organisational structure and the independence of its Secretariat help in this regard, as both are a step removed from national economic and political considerations. This facilitates policymaking and helps ensure that the focus is more prudential and long-term. Otherwise, it might be shaped purely by short-term economic and political factors, which may not be consistent with designing long-term policies to promote financial stability."

PM11:40am

Exane view: It sounds like a great deal of compromise has gone into the finalisation of Basel III and that in part will reflect a desire to ensure broad implementation of the proposals. That said, the Committee still sees its independence as important and therefore will not be forced into a position simply because it fears that certain jurisdictions will cease to adopt the standards. Whether such a lack of adoption by certain countries actually happens remains to be seen - Germany for example said as recently as last week that an output floor was a no go. Our view is that the standards signed off in January will be largely adopted across the UK and Europe. Not to do so would raise questions of transparency and comparability which would not be helpful for stakeholders more generally. It is also worth remembering that while the Basel Committee has no legal enforcement power and relies on the commitment of the jurisdictions at the table to adopt the standards, those at the table do represent 27 jurisdictions and 45 member organisations from around the world.

11:40 am
Barclays PLC (BARC:LSE): Last: 216.70, up 0.75 (+0.35%), High: 219.05, Low: 214.45, Volume: 16.14m
undefined
BE11:41am

(@Alchemy30: what's that? I've been buried in other stuff all morning.)

11:41 am

BE11:41am

PM11:41am

11:43 am

Done banks, done miners, time for telcos. That's our usual path through the market these days.

Talktalk Telecom Group PLC (TALK:LSE): Last: 155.80, down 3.9 (-2.44%), High: 157.40, Low: 145.20, Volume: 2.93m
PM11:43am

Ofcom here: http://www.investe...1612010700066278Q/

11:44 am
BE11:44am

Also, Caz has downgraded. It's watched the shares fall from 260p to 155p, then reacted at the opportune moment.

BE11:44am

Talking a divi cut.

BE11:45am

The significant pullback in the shares post 1H17 results reflects increased uncertainty about the future trading prospects for the company. We expect this uncertainty to persist until at least FY results in May-17 as the company attempts to reverse customer losses in its core consumer broadband business. Execution risk remains high, in our view, and a failure to stabilize the retail customer base could lead to further downgrades to consensus estimates.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

So, underweight from neutral with a "March 2018" price target of 150p.

BE11:46am

(Against a "March 2017" target of 230p previously, in case you care.)

BE11:46am

At 1H results, management reaffirmed the intention to pay a full year dividend at least in line with the prior year level (15.9p/share or £150m). Management acknowledged that this level of dividend would not be covered by net cash flow. In light of the current trading environment, we believe a more conservative dividend policy (equivalent to 65% of EPS) would be appropriate. This would provide a bigger liquidity buffer especially given the continued interest in “full fibre” network projects (including an incremental £20m injection into York).

11:47 am
BE11:47am

This is all founded on early performance of its new pricing plan -- as in, not being overly aggressive on customer acquisition but also not ramping up prices on customer who choose to stay rather than churn -- isn't working brilliantly.

BE11:48am

Also, the TV business seems to be in decline (because Youview is rubbish) and mobile doesn't seem to be a saviour.

BE11:48am

As for the safety net ......

11:48 am
BE11:48am

Whilst we consider TalkTalk a potential mid-term target for a larger UK operator, we believe the priorities of potential bidders currently lie elsewhere.

BE11:49am

BE11:49am

PM11:50am

BT Group (BT.A:LSE): Last: 354.00, down 3.1 (-0.87%), High: 356.45, Low: 352.20, Volume: 5.24m
PM11:50am

This par from Nic Fildes story this morning caught my eye

Here's Morgan Stanley to talk us through it all.

BE12:00pm

DMGT has produced a 5% EBITA beat in FY16. The outlook statement suggests consensus will edge up in FY17 by c3-4%. The new CEO is promising greater focus in the group and operational efficiency but no grand change. There are headwinds ( UK advertising, UK property transactions, no 53rd week, higher depreciation at RMS) but DMGT has a £55m exceptional in FY16 to help offset these. The jump in the oil price may help Euromoney and Events in due course. Ex Zoopla DMGT trades a 2017 p/e of 13x and EV/EBITDA of sub 10x.

12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

Increasing portfolio focus: the second priority is to increase the focus within the portfolio over time. There are benefits to spreading risk and DMGT will continue to have a diverse and balanced portfolio. There are advantages, however, to operating in fewer sectors, notably in respect of resource allocation and the implications for market share. We are undertaking a rigorous evaluation of all businesses in order to allocate resources according to individual business growth characteristics and funding requirements.
There are also opportunities for improvement and DMGT's revised strategy is built around delivering the potential within our existing portfolio. We have established clear priorities to improve our operational execution, increase the portfolio's focus and enhance our financial flexibility.
